Name:  ___                   Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
Heparin Analogues / Lipitor / shrimp / Coumadin
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
cough and hypoxia
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None

 
History of Present Illness:
Ms. ___ is a ___ with PMH of AS s/p TAVR (___), AV block s/p
PPM placement, CAD on cath in ___, HTN, HLD and remote breast
adenocarcinoma s/p lumpectomy and adjuvant chemoradiation who
presents with malaise. 

Patient was seen last week by her PCP and diagnosed with oral
herpes simplex given lesions. She was started on Valtrex and 
oral
steroids elixir on ___. On ___, she began experiencing
congestion, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea and cough. She was still
feeling unwell two days later, prompting presentation to the ED.
She denied fever, chills, chest pain, SOB, or sick contacts.

In the ED, her initial vitals were T 98.3, HR 70, BP 97/41, RR
22, and O2 sat 87% on RA. She triggered for hypoxia and was
placed on NC and given duonebs, with subsequent improvement in
oxygen saturation. Exam notable for inability to speak in full
sentences on nasal cannula. Lungs with rhonchi and wheezes
diffusely. Labs were notable for leukocytosis to 13.6 with 83.7%
neutrophils, Na 133, Cr 1.5, lactate 1.5. Flu A/B PCR negative.
Blood cultures were sent. CXR demonstrated mildly patchy
pneumonia in each lower lobe. The patient was given duonebs, 1L
LR, azithromycin 500mg PO and ceftriaxone 1g IV. 

Vitals prior to transfer were T 98.3, HR 74, BP 110/30, RR 14, 
O2
sat 92% on RA. On arrival to the floor, patient confirms the
above story, but does note that symptoms began about 1 week ago.
She endorses sore throat, nonproductive cough, congestion, 
nausea
and vomiting. She also reports diarrhea, at most about 4 times
per day, with last episode the day prior to presentation. She
denies blood in diarrhea. She denies fevers. She reports the 
cold
sore on her lip has resolved and she thinks the lesions under 
her
tongue have resolved as well. She finished the dexamethasone 
oral
elixir but still had 2 days of Valtrex left. She feels her
breathing is comfortable on nasal cannula, but denies having 
home
oxygen.  

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS:
==================
Per HPI, otherwise, 10-point review of systems was within normal
limits.

IMAGING:
========
___ Echo Report 
CONCLUSION:
The left atrial volume index is normal. No thrombus/mass is seen 
in the body of the left atrium (best excluded by TEE). There is 
mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with a normal cavity 
size. There is normal regional and global left ventricular 
systolic function. Quantitative 3D volumetric left ventricular 
ejection fraction is 66 % (normal 54-73%). Left ventricular 
cardiac index is normal (>2.5 L/min/m2). There is no resting 
left ventricular outflow tract gradient. Normal right 
ventricular cavity size with normal free wall motion. Tricuspid 
annular plane systolic excursion (TAPSE) is normal. The aortic 
sinus diameter is normal for gender with normal ascending aorta 
diameter for gender. The aortic arch diameter is normal with a 
normal descending aorta diameter. An Evolut aortic valve 
bioprosthesis is present. The prosthesis is well seated with 
normal leaflet motion and gradient. The effective orifice area 
index is normal (>=0.85 cm2/m2). There is no aortic 
regurgitation. The mitral valve leaflets appear structurally 
normal with no mitral valve prolapse. There is severe mitral 
annular calcification. There is minimal functional mitral 
stenosis from the prominent mitral annular calcification. There 
is an eccentric, anteriorly directed jet of mild to moderate 
[___] mitral regurgitation. Due to acoustic shadowing, the 
severity of mitral regurgitation could be UNDERestimated. The 
pulmonic valve leaflets are not well seen. The tricuspid valve 
leaflets appear structurally normal. There is mild [1+] 
tricuspid regurgitation. Due to acoustic shadowing, the severity 
of tricuspid regurgitation may be UNDERestimated. There is mild 
pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. There is no pericardial 
effusion.

IMPRESSION: Well seated, normal functioning Evolut TAVR with 
normal gradient and no aortic regurgitation. Mild symmetric left 
ventricular hypertrophy with normal cavity size and regional/ 
global biventricular systolic function. Mild pulmonary artery 
systolic hypertension. Eccentric jet of mild-moderate mitral 
regurgitation with normal valve morphology. Minimal functional 
mitral stenosis due to mitral annular calcification. Compared 
with the prior TTE (images reviewed) of ___ , minimal 
functional mitral stenosis is now demonstrated.

CLINICAL IMPLICATIONS: Based on the echocardiographic findings 
and ___ ACC/AHA
recommendations, antibiotic prophylaxis IS recommended prior to 
dental cleanings and other non-sterile
procedures.
  
___ (PA & LAT)

IMPRESSION: Left lower lobe consolidation compatible with 
pneumonia, similar to slightly increased from prior.  Stable 
small left pleural effusion.
 
___ (PORTABLE AP)
IMPRESSION: 
Lungs are low volume with bibasilar atelectasis.  The left 
pleural effusion is
increased in volume.  Cardiomediastinal silhouette is the tube.  
Left-sided
pacemaker is unchanged.  No pneumothorax.

     
___ (PA & LAT)
IMPRESSION: Findings suggest mild patchy pneumonia in each lower 
lobe.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
====================
___ with PMH of AS s/p TAVR (___), AV block s/p PPM, CAD on 
ASA, and remote breast adenocarcinoma s/p lumpectomy and 
adjuvant chemoradiation p/w hypoxia and malaise c/f pneumonia 
improving with IV abx course c/b with neck tightness and pAfib 
with rapid rates to 150s. 

ACUTE/ACTIVE ISSUES:
====================
#paroxysmal Afib
Had Afib with rapid rated to 150, BP was soft ___. 1L IVF 
was given as well as metop 5IV x2 then PO was started. No prior 
hx of afib. Spontaneously converted to NSR later that same 
afternoon. Maintained on Metop 50mg PO daily. Started reduced 
dose apixaban 2.5 mg PO BID (for age and weight) for 
anticoagulation, please continue to eval need for AC. 

#Hypoxia
#Pneumonia: Patient presented with 2d of nonproductive cough.
Leukocytosis with neutrophil predominance as well as CXR 
demonstrating possible patchy pneumonia in b/l lower lobes. Flu 
PCR negative. Abx azithromycin and 7 day course of CTX. 
Initiated on NC 2L and duonebs with guifenesin and benzonatate. 
Prior to DC pt tolerated RA. ___ was consulted and recommended 
home ___. 

RESOLVED:
========
#Oral herpes simplex: Diagnosed in outpatient clinic on ___ 
given
oral lesions with plan for 7d course of Valtrex (D7: ___.
Finished oral dexamethasone elixir prior to admission. 

#Hyponatremia:
Na slightly low at 132-134, hypovolemic iso GI losses and poor
PO. Legionella neg. Resolved with adequate PO intake and IVF. 

___:
Cr elevated to 1.5 now back to 1.1, baseline ~1.0. Etiology
likely pre-renal iso vomiting/diarrheal losses and poor PO
intake. Reassuringly improved after giving fluids and good PO as
expected. Cr at discharge 0.8

CHRONIC/STABLE ISSUES:
======================
#H/o HIT: heparin products contraindicated 

#HTN: initially held home amlodipine 5mg qd, STOPPED prior to DC 
as metoprolol was started

#Depression: cont home citalopram 10mg qd

#HLD: cont home pravastatin 80 qd

#CAD
#AS s/p TAVR
#AV block s/p PPM 
cont home ASA 81

#Osteoporosis: cont home calcium carbonate 1250 mg qd, vit D3 
1000u qd

# CODE: Full, confirmed 
# CONTACT: ___ (daughter) ___

Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
hypoxic respiratory failure secondary to community acquired 
pneumonia
paroxysmal atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response 
to 150s

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,  
 
It was a privilege caring for you at ___.  
Please see below for more information on your hospitalization. 
 
WHY WERE YOU ADMITTED TO THE HOSPITAL?  
- You were not feeling well and had a cough 
 
WHAT WAS DONE WHILE YOU WERE IN THE HOSPITAL?  
- We did an XRAY which showed an infection in your lungs 
(pneumonia), for this we stared antibiotics
- Your oxygen levels were low. We provided you with supplemental 
oxygen and monitored your levels. Your breathing improved and 
you were able to breathe comfortably on room air
- You developed an abnormal heart rhythm called atrial 
fibrillation. We started you on metoprolol to control your heart 
rates. Your heart rhythm went back to normal. 
- We discussed the atrial fibrillation with your outpatient PCP 
and cardiologist and started you on apixaban to reduced your 
stroke risk. 
 
WHAT DO YOU NEED TO DO WHEN YOU LEAVE THE HOSPITAL?  
- Take all of your medications as prescribed (listed below)  
- Follow up with your doctors as listed below    
- Seek medical attention if you have new or concerning symptoms. 


It was a pleasure taking part in your care here at ___!  
We wish you all the best!  
- Your ___ Care Team  
 
Followup Instructions:
___

qafib.question: Does the note describe the patient as having permanent, paroxysmal, or persistent afib?

qprior_stroke.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having a stroke or transient ischemic attack?

qarterial_hypertension.question: Does the note describe the patient as having arterial hypertension on treatment (high bp e.g. >140, or HTN)?

qt2d.question: Does the note describe the patient as having Diabetes mellitus (DM1, DM2, T2D, T1DM, T2DM)?

qheart_failure.question: Does the note describe the patient as having heart failure?

qsurgical_valvular_disease.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having valvular disease requiring surgery (stenosis)?

qafib_ablation.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a planned or past ablation procedure for afib?

qbleeding.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a serious bleeding in the past 6 months?

qpeptic_ulcer_disease.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having peptic ulcer disease?

qrecent_stroke.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a stroke during this admission or within the last month? (Answer yes for any recent stroke if the date is unclear)

qhemorrhagic.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having any hemorrhagic tendencies or blood dyscrasias?

qbipolar.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with bipolar disorder?

qschizophrenia.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with schizophrenia or any schizoaffective disorders?

qmdd.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with depression or major depressive disorder (MDD)?

qmed_decisions.question: Does the note describe the patient as being unable to make medical decisions? (Answer no unless there is evidence the patient cannot make their own medical decisions).

qchads2.question: What is the highest CHADS2 score mentioned? Answer "NA" if no CHADS2 score is in the note.

qblood_glucose.question: What is the highest blood glucose lab mentioned? Answer "NA" if no blood glucose score is in the note.

qlvef.question: What is the lowest left ventricular ejection (LVEF, ef, ejection fraction) fraction mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no LVEF is in the note, Answer 55 if the lowest value is 55% or greater.

qPLT.question: What is the lowest platelet count (PLT) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no platelet count is available in the note.

qHGB.question: What is the lowest hemoglobin (HGB) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no HGB value is available in the note.

qCREAT.question: What is the higest serum creatinine (Creat) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no creatinine value is available in the note.

qAST.question: What is the higest aspartate aminotransferase level (AST) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no AST value is available in the note.

qBILI.question: What is the higest total bilirubin (TotBili, Bili) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no bilirubin value is available in the note.
